skill.name: matchms
skill.description: Mass spectrometry analysis. Process mzML/MGF/MSP, spectral similarity (cosine, modified cosine), metadata harmonization, compound ID, for metabolomics and MS data processing.
skill.summary: Mass spectrometry analysis. Process mzML/MGF/MSP, spectral similarity (cosine, modified cosine), met...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files. No executable code, no network operations, no file system access beyond its own directory, no environment variable access. Purely informational content for the matchms Python library.

content.value_statement: Mass spectrometry generates complex spectral data that requires specialized processing. Matchms provides a complete Python toolkit for loading, filtering, comparing, and identifying compounds from spectral data with established similarity metrics.
actual_capabilities: Import and export spectra from mzML, MGF, MSP, JSON, and pickle formats
Apply 40+ filters for metadata harmonization, peak normalization, and quality control
Calculate spectral similarities using cosine, modified cosine, and fingerprint methods
Build reproducible processing pipelines with SpectrumProcessor
Derive chemical structures (InChI, SMILES, fingerprints) from spectral metadata
Compare spectra against reference libraries for compound identification
limitations: Requires Python environment to run matchms library operations
Chemical structure features require rdkit dependency
Does not perform de novo structure elucidation without reference libraries
Large library comparisons may require significant computational resources

use_cases.title: Identify unknown metabolites
use_cases.description: Match experimental spectra against reference libraries to identify metabolites in complex biological samples

use_cases.title: Standardize data processing
use_cases.description: Create consistent preprocessing pipelines for processing high-throughput LC-MS/MS data

use_cases.title: Compare spectral libraries
use_cases.description: Compare multiple spectral libraries to find duplicate entries and similar compounds across datasets

prompt_templates.title: Load and inspect spectra
prompt_templates.prompt: Load spectra from an MGF file using matchms and show the first 3 spectra with their compound names and precursor m/z values

prompt_templates.title: Preprocess spectral data
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply default_filters, normalize_intensities, and select_by_relative_intensity to a list of spectra, then save the processed results

prompt_templates.title: Search reference library
prompt_templates.prompt: Match query spectra against a reference library using CosineGreedy similarity, and return the top 5 matches for each query with their scores

prompt_templates.title: Build multi-metric pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a pipeline that adds chemical fingerprints, calculates both CosineGreedy and FingerprintSimilarity scores, and combines them with custom weights for robust compound identification

output_examples.input: Load spectra from spectra.mgf and identify compounds
output: Processing with default filters and similarity scoring:

best_practices: Apply the same processing pipeline to both reference and query spectra for consistent comparison
Use PrecursorMzMatch as a fast pre-filter before calculating computationally expensive similarity scores
Save processed spectra as pickle files for faster reloading in iterative workflows
anti_patterns: Skipping metadata harmonization when combining spectra from different instruments or sources
Using CosineHungarian for very large library comparisons without pre-filtering
Comparing spectra without normalizing intensities first

faq.question: What file formats does matchms support for importing spectra?
faq.answer: Matchms supports MGF, MSP, mzML, mzXML, JSON (GNPS format), pickle, and USI references from metabolomics repositories.

faq.question: Which similarity metric should I use for initial library searching?
faq.answer: CosineGreedy provides the best balance of speed and accuracy for most applications. Use ModifiedCosine when comparing spectra with different precursor masses.

faq.question: How does matchms compare to GNPS for spectral matching?
faq.answer: Matchms provides similar functionality to GNPS but runs locally, offering more control over processing parameters and faster iteration for research workflows.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using matchms?
faq.answer: Matchms processes all data locally in your Python environment. No data is sent to external servers unless you explicitly load from online USI references.

faq.question: Why are my similarity scores lower than expected?
faq.answer: Ensure both query and reference spectra are processed with the same filters. Check that intensities are normalized and low-intensity peaks are consistently filtered.

faq.question: Can matchms run on Windows, macOS, and Linux?
faq.answer: Yes, matchms is a cross-platform Python library that works on all major operating systems where Python is supported.
